Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: Identity-attack and Non-identity-attack. Anything harsh or derogatory regarding someone's identity, such as their looks, race, gender, or sexual orientation, is considered an identity attack.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Comment: You're oversimplifying (again).  What happened to Whole Foods is the same thing that happens to a lot of businesses that come in and disrupt a market:  Competition from the big box guys.  

When Whole Foods started growing the big box, publicly traded grocers saw the threat to their never ending hunger for more and more profit.  So they looked at ways to compete.  One way was to start offering higher-end things in their stores than they had before.  Things like "butcher cut" meats, a seafood counter, more of a selection of better cheeses, higher quality and organic produce, etc.

The typical WF shopper would  go to Whole Foods to get the things that they couldn't get at the "regular" grocery store, and then go big box for the rest of their staples, etc.  Once the big box stores started offering the higher end stuff people, whose lives are busy enough as it is just started doing all of their shopping back at the big box store.

A similar thing is happening on the craft beer front.

Comment: Alan's and Rebecca's comments remind us of how much has changed since the 1980's when Japan was ascendant and the U.S. dollar was weak. The dollar is now strong, and U.S. housing market is still recovering from the hammering it took in the Great recession. The U.S. Dept. of Commerce prohibits export of state-owned timber, but privately-owned wood can be sold into whatever market provides the highest price for the owner.  That's as it should be.  People and corporations should be free to sell their products wherever they choose - making & exporting things builds wealth.  Government control of markets always produces distortions and inefficiencies.  That's not an argument for no regulation, but it is an argument for the lightest possible regulation.  Clallam timber, both private and state-owned has been "exported" from our County for many decades. Since state-owned wood supplies Clallam mills, the 92 million board feet not harvested has hastened the demise of Clallam mills - no question.

Comment: The pontifical secret applies to “extrajudicial denunciations”, an allegation of child sexual abuse made to the superior of the accused. It does not apply where a curate is told about the abuse of his parish priest, but vice versa it does. It does not apply where a bishop walks into a priest’s bedroom and finds him abusing a child. His knowledge come from his own eyes and not from any extrajudicial denunciation or any inquiry that he might set up. But these are unusual circumstances. Most of the bishops’ knowledge comes from someone complaining to him about the abuse by a priest under his control, and those allegations are covered by the secret. Those who accidentally come across this information are also bound by the secret. Francis knows about the secret because the Argentinian protocol which was two years in the drafting, was signed off by his fellow bishops one month after he became pope. Art 17 states “as a first warning” that these cases are subject to the pontifical secret.

Comment: Regarding the so-called 'Nordic model', a lot of it depends on the country. Norway has a higher level of state-ownership than the other Scandinavian states. There is a lot of apples to oranges comparisons when you talk about North America vs nordic countries.

One thing common to successful left wing movements, and I tend to think that successful right wing government policies have the same, is putting pragmatism and economic realism over ideology. For example, while Sweden is still a very progressive social democracy, in the 1990s they steeply cut income taxes in order to spur economic growth.

IMO, it matters less what position you start from than whether you are willing to honestly assess the consequences of policies, and prioritize sustainability.

Comment: I hope that he wins!  It's about time that the federal government gets out of those areas that are constitutionally provincial responsibilities.  I have never understood why I send my tax money to Victoria AND Ottawa for healthcare, education etc.  This forces my provincial government to have to beg Ottawa for the money that I sent them for my services.  Federal politicians have always found it too tempting to promise to improve provincial services, so they promise amazing improvements for services that they aren't even delivering, and tax us accordingly.  
The beauty of Bernier's platform is that it leaves provincial responsibilities to the provinces.  His platforms doesn't turn Canada into a right wing Libertarian country, it merely lets provinces decide, on their own how they want to deliver services.  Quebec can be socialist, BC conservative and the federal government will stay out of the way and focus on their core responsibilities such as military/diplomacy/economic policy etc.

Comment: "The Justice Department asked Watson to clarify that the order only applied to the ban on travel from six mostly Muslim countries and not a global freeze on refugees entering the United States."

His Honor Judge Watson is perfectly correct that there is nothing in his order related to this question that requires the slightest clarification.  To quote from his order:

"It is hereby ADJUDGED, ORDERED, and DECREED that:  Defendants ... are hereby enjoined from enforcing or implementing Sections 2 and 6 of the Executive Order across the Nation."

Section 6 is precisely the section that addresses the 120-day "global freeze on refugees".  Judge Watson specifically enjoins enforcement or implementation of Section 6.  Nothing could be clearer.

Trump may not like the judge's ruling, and perhaps the Justice Dept. believes it has a better chance of successfully appealing Section 6.  But the government's request for clarification is utterly without merit and Watson's rejection of it is proper.

Comment: Anne,

Is there any way for Disney to make this right?  Or is it your opinion that white storytellers should never be allowed to retell Polynesian/Hawaiian stories? Do you believe that whites should only tell the stories of their own or other white cultures, no matter their intentions?

Recall Disney caught a wave of backlash in the early 90's because they were only telling the stories of white princesses. This outrage led to their production of Alladin, Pochohantas, Mulan. It wasn't meant to be appropriation, it was supply meeting demand.  So, some minorities want their stories told, others do not.  Luckily for them, Disney is in the business of making money, not of making every last person happy with what they're doing.

That said, what you're doing with this editorial is the best way to make a change. You can't force a company with the resources of Disney to not make a certain movie. But you can create a big enough stink that they don't do it again. Hopefully, enough people agree.

Comment: They do, just as in American popular opinion, WWII was won by us.
Russia took the brunt of the German Army effort. Even after D-Day, I believe there were way more German troops on the Eastern Front. Most Americans don't have a clue about the Great Patriotic War, as the Russians call their WWII effort.
I've given this some thought. There is no doubt in my mind that, if at some point Russia surrendered and Hitler and Stalin reached a peace agreement, millions of German troops would have been diverted westward, with their tanks, artillery pieces, airplanes, etc, which would have made the invasion of France far more difficult, And, had D-Day failed, it would have taken time for the Western Allies to try a second effort, if one was launched at all. All of Eastern Europe was still in German hands. Churchill might have been forced to resign. And Germany would have been able to re-direct troops to the Eastern Front and might have fought Russia to a standstill.
It required a joint effort.

Comment: In 1991, Crimea voted 94.3% in favour to leave Ukraine and become an autonomous republic of the USSR. Of course, the USSR disbanded later in 1991, and Crimea became an autonomous region in Ukraine.
In 1994, Crimea's independence and pro-Russia movement was growing, and Crimea formed a separatist government.
the UN polled Crimea quarterly from 2009 - 2011, and each time found that a majority of Crimean residents wanted to rejoin Russia.
In 2014, around the time of the Maiden coup in Kiev, and pre-referendum in Crimea, various international pollsters found that nearly 80% of polled Crimean residents wanted to rejoin Russia.
Post Crimean referendum, many international pollsters investigated the satisfaction of Crimeans with the referendum outcome, and typically found that over 85% of Crimeans were fully satisfied with the referendum outcome, while further Crimeans were mostly or generally satisfied with the referendum outcome.
The polling of Crimea is consistent and clear.

Comment: The global warming crowd are the ones who are being frankly stupid (your words) on the pipeline issue to my reckoning.

Blocking export of oil from Alberta is not going to magically reduce the amount of oil used in the world.  That will be lessened only by replacing energy from oil with energy from other sources, which is happening, but will take time.

In the meantime, if the US and other countries don't get heavy oil from Alberta, they'll get it from Mexico or Venezuela or African countries that have far lower environmental standards and certainly no cap on carbon emissions -- which is to say, it would result in higher greenhouse gas emissions.

My only caveat in this argument is that there's no guarantee that Alberta won't just turn around and elect an irresponsible right-wing government that drops the cap on emissions.

Comment: There're 2 levels of culpability in situations like the health-firings controversy: (a) the senior career public servants (i) directly responsible for the supervision the work of those fired and (ii) who conducted the disciplinary hearings involved, and (b) the Cabinet Ministers politically responsible for the administration of the Health Ministry and Government handling of the the fallout over those firings through the years.

After much delay and obfuscation, we finally have a public report flowing from an official inquiry which makes it clear that responsible senior career public servants acted badly and bear responsibility for much harm done.  

What is lacking is adequate recognition of and redress for the serious harm that flowed and continues to flow from the delays, obfuscations and refusal to take action and political responsibility by Premier Clark and her Cabinet Colleagues for their cynical role throughout.

Comment: It is not economic for the railroad, nor has it ever been. There are currently ports on the rail belt that are on year-round, ice free, deep water and they are cumulatively less than 10% utilized. In addition to the extensively reported tidal and ice issues, some years ago the tramp steamers used to move resources were questioned about Port McKenzie and no one was able to find an operator willing to commit to call on the port during the winter months. This project will add infrastructure and heavy maintenance cost due to the geology and the snowfall but there is no identified source of additional or new revenue for the railroad. Any reasonable resource project would be cheaper to ship via one of the ice-free ports. This project has been political from the beginning and there has never been a defensible economic case.

Comment: The layoffs are a bummer. Not a secret by any stretch.

If you're asking me where they came from, I'd probably say they're mainly because 1) the regulatory environment, and 2) the global demand for hybrid seed. 
The regulatory environment in Hawaii is notoriously capricious and hostile, and these absurd anti-GMO laws are prime examples. They get passed by politicians and activists without consideration for the downstream effects, go to court and are litigated away for millions and millions, then come back in another, slightly-different form. 
As for the demand for hybrid seed: it fluctuates, and at this point the supply is higher than the demand. It'll probably go back up (since farmers overwhelmingly prefer hybrid seed to traditional), but not soon enough for the kids on Molokai who have to move to Oahu to get good jobs.

Comment: As a former smoker, I couldn't agree more. I quit 6 years ago and never have missed it once since getting over the initial withdrawal symptoms.  They say addiction to nicotine is the hardest to quit, yet people do it every day on their own with no expensive treatments or psychiatry.  There were times during the first 6 months after I quit I felt like my skin was crawling and had vivid smoking dreams.  I'd  have dreams where I was smoking a cigarette and wake up actually  smelling the smoke. Back then I'd give almost anything to stay quit, but now, you couldn't pay me enough to take even one puff.  I don't believe quitting drugs is much different. It takes grim determination and a strong will to overcome the addiction. Anyone can get addicted and anyone can quit.

The families of drug addicts get tired of being victimized by the family member who selfishly does drugs at the expense of everyone around them, including themselves. They get tired of broken promises and fake sorrow.

Thinking of the deaths of my own parents many years ago, when they died my first priority was not to notify the county's poll workers. I'm sure my parents remained on the rills for several years before voting inactivity removed them.  No harm, no foul, as they say.

Comment: Having been hiking solo in the park since I came up here in the 1970's and attending many park classes and events along with many wins in the Denali Road Lottery. The federal park staff are experts at training visitors on how to avoid bear conflicts, how to store your food in bear proof containers (which are available)  and what do in case of a bear attack that you have to participate in or you do not get a permit to use the park for hiking and camping in the park itself and not just go on a public or private bus trip through the park. The park staff ride make their rounds on the road system of the park and they often stop traffic on the road when bears are on or near the road. They are not "nice" they are tough on park users when a bear is sighted and they let you know in no uncertain terms when to back off and leave the bear alone. I have never seen the park rangers being anything but serious when it comes to wildlife encounters when it involves public safety. They are on the job!

Comment: It's easy to put the stewardship argument on the shoulders of the doctor. However, patient accountability/stewardship is also an important factor that is often not discussed (political suicide). There are many patients who come for 3rd, 4th, 5th opinions and are told the exact same thing. Patients who demand blood work and other investigations. Patients who have family doctors but go to ERs as the time is more convenient etc. This is driven by the fact patients do not know the costs to the healthcare system for such visits.  There are some countries that limit the # of '2nd opinions' people can seek, but again introducing this will likely be political suicide.
Overall though there needs to be a closer look at our healthcare system structure, payment models, as the current climate of having doctors work even harder, longer hours, for less pay is going to end up looking like the NHS doctor exodus.

Comment: You lost me with your second paragraph.   The errors of Vatican I?

What you've said clarifies what I alluded to earlier in another comment:   Many of those who like "smells and bells" and chant are just as distant from real Catholicism as the "liberal side" is.  

Christ founded the Catholic Church on the Rock which is Peter.   Christ prayed for Peter that Peter's Faith would fail not.   Peter became the first pope after the Resurrection, when Christ told Peter to Feed His Sheep.  

Vatican I, as well as any ecumenical council confirmed by a pope, cannot contain error when it teaches on faith or morals solemnly to the universal Church.   

Numerous popes (such as Eugene IV) have taught ex cathedra that there is no salvation outside the Church.   Almost no one assents to this today.  Even groups like SSPX, SSPV, and CMRI reject this Dogma.  

With most liturgical conservatives today, there is no real Faith:   just a bunch of incense and fancy chasubles with no solid Faith underneath.

Comment: If the funding for such assistance can be attributed to local sources, perhaps there is a point to be made; the civil responsibility would be to help others. That is what 'society' and civilization implies. Of course a suburb or small town near Seattle could easily accommodate most of Alaska's total number, & not flinch.

I'd rather see the government have 'a little scratch' so as to react to unplanned things, such as emergencies; I prefer to allow room for that unexpected cost or unplanned future that nobody seems to be all that good at forecasting. Seems to me (and several hundred people I know here) that if we sell everything our government has to some private group, we'll be paying much more, with much less representation. 

The answer is to get big money out of local & national politics; try & be involved, don't simply just vote -- after all the major dust has settled. And don't take no wooden nickels.

Comment: We didn't ask for additional comment. I felt the explanation the mayor provided with the bill was sufficient. Clearly you disagree, but does anything really change? Comment: The proposal for a pro-rated property tax based on income is the best suggestion that has been put forward thus far and I'm glad to see more people are endorsing it.  This doesn't only catch foreign investors but domestic speculators and tax cheats as well.

Ultimately, the contribution to the local economy via expenditure and income taxes is a lot more than property taxes.  So, triple or quadruple property taxes and provide a credit based on income taxes that are declared.

In this way, people that are cheating on their taxes have to pay more, people who leave their homes empty will have to pay more and overseas or out of town investors will also have to pay more.  

The people that will benefit are the hard-working locals who pay their fair share of taxes - take the extra money from the increased property taxes and reduce income taxes for this group or invest in affordable housing.

Comment: I don't think anyone holds special knowledge. I am using the analogy of the burning bush because the events in the Bible are all justified through their miraculous nature. The Bible isn't a pure philosophy. The events in the Bible are meant to be taken literally. Jesus was born a virgin, was crucified, and rose from the dead. 

The thing I'm digging at is that these isolated events do not justify the whole. If we discovered a burning bush like Moses saw in the Bible then many would see that as justification for the Bible being literally true. But in reality that would just point to a burning-bush phenomena in the desert. Maybe it has some correlation to the Bible. But that's not logical to say it justifies the whole. Much of religious doctrine is built this way. This bible verse justifies that one and so on. The Bible doesn't actually work this way, people just say it does. It's circular.

What you are doing takes a measure of faith. With that faith should go humility, not judgement.

Stephen J. Remington

Comment: The success of the Kuleana Academy is due to the participation and support of a whole lot of people, including the HAPA Board of Directors, generous donors and especially program manager Aria Castillo. Participants are instructed by highly qualified professionals with direct experience dealing in politics and policy making.  Subjects covered include public speaking, message development, campaign management, fund-raising etc.  Participants are also taught fundamental personal basics such as that in order to win, you must be willing to lose.  It is this key personality trait that I believe separate the “doers” from the “talkers”.  In total, I have been a candidate in 10 different elections over the past 20 or so years, winning 6 of those campaigns and losing 4.  Frankly, it is through the losses that the most important lessons are learned.  I share my knowledge and experience with participants but that is only one small part of the over-all education and training that occurs.

A Critical Evaluation of the Effects of Safe Injection Facilities 
Garth Davies, Simon Fraser University

Conclusion: Taking Causality Seriously
On the subject of the effects of SIFs, the available research is overwhelmingly positive. Comment: (cont) 
As for "dividends are what are paid to investors" - what is your point?  That the company cuts a check or does an electronic transfer?  So what?  That money is a return on investment, much more similar to interest on a CD, not anything like a wage.  A wage is PAID to employees for time worked, dividends are PAID to shareholders, aka owners.  Simply because a payment is made doesn't make one thing the same as another. 

You can propose, if you wish, that all income regardless of source ought to be taxed the same.  But when you declare absolutely that income from an investment in a company, aka a dividend, is exactly the same thing as a wage paid to employee, because both are "paid", it's hard to take the rest seriously. There is a long history & reason for basing taxation policy by acknowledging & rewarding risk involved in obtaining income, because it's in the interest of our country that people take those risks to expand the economy.  That's unlikely to change.

Comment: There is no justification for the continuation of this dynamic. There is no free market justification (because the market is the least free in Canada already). There is no long-term economic growth rationale (nothing outside of real estate is growing and when you lose your future tax base and essential skills, you’re are not thriving). There is no moral reasoning (because you can’t justify eating your young).

I don’t deny that fixing this will hurt. Hangovers hurt. But trying to drink them away only makes them bigger – and it’s what we’ve been doing for years. Every little measure the government does to “help buyers” now is the same as trying to drink away a hangover. And every year we delay righting this policy imbalance exacerbates the problem for a growing number of Canadians.

Comment: Your two geologists seem to be outliers. Berman says high oil prices caused the recent recession. But those high prices were a spike that quickly dropped. The nearly singular cause was the collapse of US financial institutions leading to a world crisis and the evaporation of trillions in highly leveraged assets. Our recent, pre-glut oil price highs didn't affect the recovery to a noticeable extent. The current glut was engineered by the Saudis, to prevent the Iranian recovery and the reopening of the Shia-controlled Iraqi oil fields. This glut is the sole reason for the deliberate reductions in tight oil production in the US.

The USGS has called the Bakken play "the largest continuous petroleum accumulation it has ever assessed," with at least 5 billion barrels potential production. Comment: that really depends on prior conditions.  Scolytids can only attack trees under various forms of stress in normal conditions, and can only attack healthy vigorous trees when their populations get to epidemic levels.  Defoliating insects such as the spruce aphid or the spruce budworm can and do take down healthy trees, but it takes several years of repeated attack to burn down a tree's starch reserves.  For example, most of the Sitkas in Homer that are currently under attack will be back to 100% canopy within eight years.  Large insect attacks such as the Pine beetle epidemic in Canada and the Western U.S., or those observed in the Kenai in the previous three decades are reliant upon conditions that are both favorable to insect survival (such as warmer winters, which decrease frost mortality), and detrimental to the forest.  Large stands of primarily overmature trees, such as those of the Cooper Landing area in the 80s are highly vulnerable to stress, and easily overwhelmed by beetles.

What will be the impact of global warming and in a world of approaching eight billion humans, what can realistically be done to eliminate human generated climate change.  The science surrounding the predictions of what a few degrees of warming will do to the world is much more complex than the prediction of the warming itself.  Countries like Canada, Russia, Norway, Sweden, Finland, etc. would benefit greatly from warming.  Greenland could truly be green.  Tropical forests are lush.  Increased CO2 may add vigor to plant growth.  The real science is in determining consequences.  Trump and crew apparently believe that a warmer world will not be so bad.  That is a tenable scientific position.

Comment: I support any and all initiatives that will stop this illegal activity. However, my reasons have very little to do with security issues.

My issues are the cost and the unfairness.

We have a process established to immigrate to Canada that most people wishing to immigrate here respect and follow. The integrity of that lawful process is falling badly. Why bother with protocol and proper channels when you can just take a cab to the general area of the border and walk right in?

To allow, virtually encourage, this activity is grossly unfair to those doing it properly.

There is only one way that this will not excelerate in frequency. We must start sending them back and make it known that this shortcut no longer works. If we do not, then surely the numbers will grow and the cost will become a real issue.

Again, I am not particularly concerned about terrorist threats from this source. It is simply unfair and potentially very expensive.

Comment: Passive investments held inside a company don't get the small business "active" income rate of approx. 14%, they are taxed much higher at approx. 48%.  The company gets a refund of 26.67% of the tax paid on investment income when it pays out a dividend to a shareholder, who in turn pays personal tax.  With the new rules the government is not refunding any tax to the company, resulting in a combined tax rate, in some situations, of approx. 73%.  So you take all the risk and the government takes all the upside.  The rules, as is, are meant to force people to pay out dividends to get their refundable tax back.  The system, as is,  works.  The government's proposed systems appears to be a convoluted tax grab.

Comment: It's the right decision.  The whole point of the Establishment Clause was to stop the State from forcing people to participate in a certain religion.  That doesn't mean that the State is not permitted to provide financial support to any religion, nor does it mean that the State has to treat all religions the same.  It's about the government allowing people to freely practice the religion of their choice.

This "separation of church and state" nonsense should never have been used as legal reasoning in any of the Court's decisions.  The phrase carries no legal weight.

Comment: The last day is not for another 3 weeks (January 20), but Matson ponied up the bucks to take two sleds (Zirkle and Moore) off the auction block preemptively, and for thousands more than the average sled price.  They COULD have simply gone along and bumped the highest bid up by $100 at a time and perhaps gotten them cheaper, but they didn't.  Yes, they did it to get their people the rides.  But it cost them $15K.  And anyone with deep pockets can do the same thing with any of the remaining sleds (including those being driven by folks like Dallas Seavey, Mitch Seavey, John Baker, and Jeff King).  Or you can go with competitive bidding.  But it is an auction, and at every auction I've ever attended, the highest bid gets the item.  Or, as a friend of mine once told me:  "You know that you just paid more for that than anyone else in the room thought it was worth?"

Comment: Good work by Senator Riviere, as usual. 

Friends of Hanauma Bay, including my friend and neighbor Bob Kern, is working to promote more sustainable management of the Bay.  All of our resources need to be better managed—this is in essence what 'Conservation 1.0' was all about, sustainable stewardship of resources.

Imagine if Diamond Head, Punchbowl Crater's flanks, Mount Tantalus, Koko Head, Kaena Point, Laniakea, Waimea Bay, and Hanauma Bay were actually managed for restoration of native ecosystems (terrestrial are even more neglected than marine).  Yes, it's lofty, and yes, it's expensive.  But if we are truly managing tourism well, we are balancing the revenues generated (both taxes and sales) as mitigation against the impacts.  We could easily capture more tourist money without harming jobs and trips.  In fact, many tourists want to be assured that their visit is impacting the landscape and people in a beneficial way!  There is no need for enmity on this.

Comment: Yes, the Book on the Infancy of Jesus is also on the List of Apocrypha, but the infancy narratives of Christ were already part of the Canon of Scripture. So Gelasius' rejection of the book did not mean his simultaneous rejection of Jesus' nativity.

One cannot argue this, however, of his rejecting the book on the assumption of Mary. Her assumption was not part of the Canon, which suggests (not definitively) that Gelasius rejected the very idea of the assumption simply because it had no biblical support.

Pope Hormisdas reaffirmed Gelasius' decree, as you said.

Were these papal actions tantamount to declaring as heresy the teaching on Mary's assumption? In my opinion, yes.

Comment: Part 3 (continued from response to our brother Kevin)

Bear with me.  I will get to your question.

You and I are not on the same page.  There is nothing wrong with that.  Indeed, I think it is likely that it is the same God supporting each of us (and brother Kevin, as well) on our separate pages.

How can that be?  Let me suggest an explanatory model.  First premise to the model: our conceptualizations of reality -- the reality that is God's creation -- are not reality itself (what Kant would call the "ding an such").  Any conceptualization is, at best, a simplification or an idealization of reality.  We can and do improve.  We just never get to perfect.  Indeed, perfection is probably an illusion.  Reality is what it is, and our conceptions can never get there.  This is so for physics (see the progression from Aristotle to Copernicus to Newton to Einstein), but it seems reasonable as a general matter.  Note the phrase, "semper reformanda" as applied to the church.

See Part 4.

Comment: Without oil you wouldn't be fishing and neither would 99 percent of the other fishermen.
Commercial fishing has so decimated  the stocks that once prolific streams and rivers no longer have runs and many runs have to be enhanced by hatcheries. Hatcheries are the one bright point that commercial fisheries are mostly responsible for. Halibut stocks are horribly depleted, and no it wasn't the sports fishery that did it. 95 percent of halibut are allocated to the commercial fishery, 5 percent to sports fishing. 
The commercial fishing industry doesn't contribute a tenth of what the oil industry does to the economy of Alaska. It has been great for a few privileged families and the conglomerates in Seattle but not so much for the average Alaskan.

Comment: It just seems to me that today's technology makes these neat distinctions somewhat out of date. Should the Internet be ultimately under the control of a private organization or is it an important enough utility that it should be under the control of the "we the people" directly through government? There are a variety of opinions among conservatives on this question right now. 

Highways, railroads, airports are so essential to producing wealth in today's world; there are proposals for these to be provided by private enterprise, but does anyone really trust such an arrangement without considerable regulation? The "public utilities" model of organization maybe something that should be used more instead of reduced as it has been in recent years.

Is the prosperity of Canada ... Sweden ... Denmark ... etc. "a dangerous illusion"? It just seems to me that in today's realities, there are roles for government, for private enterprise, for voluntary organizations, and collaboration is needed.

Comment: I have worked with many commissioner/deputy commissioner's at DOC, and I think Mr. Williams is the first one who has a big picture view. I do know where the CO's are coming from, but the fact is that what they feel is "throwing them under the bus" is the first opportunity they have had in a long time to gain back respect. Until there was some ownership of error to the public, there was not way to build back trust. Now people are hopeful that DOC will improve and that should result in more support. He is focused on what the CO's say is important...training, transparency, and an actual understanding of the work process. His choice of Clare Sullivan as deputy commissioner is also right on. There is already an improvement of attitude from inmates and families, because they don't see DOC as this blank wall to hate anymore, but as an organization trying to recognize failures and make things better. And none of the CO's I know are against him...but say union and management are.

Comment: Los Angeles Times  August 4, 2009

"If a package passes Congress, the pharmaceutical industry has pledged $80 billion in cost savings over 10 years to help pay for it. For his part, Tauzin said he had not only received the White House pledge to forswear Medicare drug price bargaining, but also a separate promise not to pursue another proposal Obama supported during the campaign: importing cheaper drugs from Canada or Europe. Both proposals could cost the industry billions, undermine its ability to develop new cures and, in the case of imports, possibly compromise safety, industry officials contend.

Much of the bargaining took place in July at a meeting in the Roosevelt Room, just off the Oval Office, a person familiar with the discussions said. In attendance were Tauzin, several industry chief executives -- including those from Abbott Laboratories, Merck and Pfizer -- White House Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel and White House aides."

Comment: Expensive divorce for both genders. 

Here in metro Vancouver, if you own your own home going into a relationship, given the double digit valuation increases each year, leaving a common law relationship or marriage means splitting up that huge increased difference in value. 

And that mean either getting a mortgage, or remortgaging to pay that off.

Two stories, one a father who signed over a property to his son, to help him out in a tough housing market, and the son then lost a large enough portion of that through divorce that he had to sell.  

And a second story where the spouse (this time male) in a marriage of only a few years, demanded his share of the increased home valuation after he was kicked out, for amongst other things, not working. That cost the single mom about twenty thousand dollars, most of it legal fees, and a re-mortgage.

Stories?  Reader here will have hundreds. 

Mostly - it's the money.

Comment: Hawaii DOE should start actively looking at Telepresence Teachers. The DOE is already spending a huge amount of money recruiting mainland teachers, getting them moved over, with many determining in a year or two, they can't afford to live in Hawaii. With a Telepresence Teacher, the teacher can stay on the mainland and teach classes from their more affordable area, plus have the time zone advantage for class preparation. The Telepresence Teacher would be assisted locally by local teacher's aides, providing them valuable hands-on experience. It would also be a real world daily demonstration of S.T.E.M. products and technologies, while staying pertinent to Hawaii. The personal touch could be retained by having the teacher visit for an introduction and orientation session at the beginning of the school year. Sticking to the old method isn't working and it's costing more and more with worse results. This is a business example of Telepresence.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hVviDvsBQ78

Comment: Shareholders can petition and monitor pay of management. They can also decide how much management is allowed to earn and they can control how much they earn based on results. For example (lets break this down into small numbers) if management is paid a total of ten dollars and they only produce results where shareholders earn 2 dollars then that means it costs shareholders 8 dollars to earn 2 dollars. They are losing money so no wonder they are upset. Now if you lower the pay or make management earn their pay by a percent of what shareholders earn in dividends then you have a better system and happier shareholders. Lets say shareholders expect 3.00 per share in dividends minimum. If you take 2013 $7,456,151 pay for O&D and cut it in half that leaves $3,728,082 that goes to 21,000 shareholders x 100 shares each = 2,100,000 shares = $1.77 extra per share on top of $1.54 = $3.31 per share. Bottom line is all O&D in all the corporations are overpaid but you do have the power to change it.

Comment: I have to agree.Why should anyone else have to pay for the mistakes of land owners? We had to weigh the possible repercussions and ended up turning down the house. Six months later the entire neighborhood was predictably under water according to the flood plain info we were given. I can only imagine that considering the area, any homeowner purchasing along the river was given similar info regarding the river and its erosion issues. Yet they chose to build or purchase. It's not a freak accident. It's a natural function of the river going back decades. Why should anyone else have to pony up to pay the bill now as they fall into the river

Comment: Alex, I happen to agree with you.  The question in this case specifically really isn't whether one thinks taking such photos is a good or a bad idea.  The issues are that the photos were of an underage girl, were stolen and then were shared.

There are other important problems that can be addressed, too.  What consenting adults choose to do is none of my business.  However, the fact that this kind of behavior is rampant among young people shows a disregard or lack of understanding about how likely it is that such photos will come back to haunt them.  It also suggests that, if the photos are taken by someone of someone else underage, the result is child pornography.  Considering the relative naievete of many kids, it's unlikely those thoughts occur to them.

In the end, the whole thing suggests a need for more education, hopefully by the parents.  Failing that, it would be an excellent addition to existing classroom discussions about sex and reproductive health.

Comment: The sad reality is:  silencers, while currently regulated in the U.S., are very easy to fabricate for anybody who is motivated.   Same with converting a semi-automatic rifle into a fully automatic (which is legal to do in the U.S. and can be done for as little as $100).   So the debates over legislation regarding things like silencers or regulating assault rifles are missing the big picture.    

The real debate is over the gun culture of the U.S. and it's connection to the founding father's "right to bear arms" via the second amendment.    Eg:  for the sake of argument, you could advocate that EVERY household have one gun and one gun only to satisfy the 2nd amendment.    Every additional gun would be subject to rigid background checks.    That still wouldn't solve the number of guns already in circulation and the ability to circumvent the laws (strictly because the number of guns in circulation is already huge).   

It will take a generational change and will get worse before better.

Comment: I have never claimed that defendants always tell the truth, but they have a disadvantage in that juries are more likely to believe police testimony.

Police aren't the only ones who lie, but they have the advantage of seeming more credible to judges and juries.  Ordinary citizens should be protected from police lies by requiring police to record every interaction with the public. 

I would hope that the cop who comes when a husband is beating his family would have a body camera to record him doing so. I would hope that the cop's dash camera would be there to record the drunken driver, to ensure that a jury would have access to the most truthful testimony. 

Video evidence isn't just to protect civilians, but it is the best way to counteract untruthful testimony.

Comment: I agree with Mr. Maynard's thesis and applaud his 4 point plan, however for me the elephant in the room is risk. As I'm sure Mr. Maynard would agree, carrying on with the status quo is certainly risky, but these risks are hidden and their timing unknown. "Actively investing in true innovation" brings with it immediate and obvious business and personal risk to the SME founders, owners and employees and hence serves as a disincentive and affects "atiitude." As I see it, we need to foster an "attitude" of more healthy competition, collaboration, teamwork and mentoring to leverage our collective experiences in order to reduce the inherent risks. This in turn should encourage more external investment and tax policy can also help, as no SME founder/owner wants to (or should) risk both his job/livelihood and his savings.  We also need to develop an "attitude" that failure is a valuable learning experience and that most of those who do fail are now worthy of investing in a second time.

Comment: Dividends and income are taxes at virtually the exact same rate.  The only difference is that for dividends some of the taxation is classified as "corporate tax" while some of the tax is classified as "personal tax" while with income it is all classified as "personal tax".

At the end of the day though if a company earns $100,000 before tax and pays it all to one individual both that individual and the government will receive the same amount of money whether it is paid as a dividend or as income.

Capital gains are a bit of a different story.  Some money earned from capital gains is paid after corporate tax has been collected, but it isn't quite as direct of a relationship as with dividends.  One could make arguments in favour of raising the capital gains inclusion rate but one could also argue that one of the biggest problems hurting Canada's economy is the difficulty attracting domestic investment money.

Comment: No.
Corporate tax is on the net income.  If the contractor is working for his corporation on salary, he pays the same personal income tax as any employee for his salary. The salary is a deduction for the company.   If he is paid in divdends, then corporate tax is paid on the entire corporate net income, and he also pays personal tax on his dividend, which brings the total tax up to what he would have paid if he was taking a salary.
.After corporate tax is paid, he has $85000 left in retained earnings.  He invests the retained earnings.  The Corporate tax he will pay in the future is on the interest earned on the $85,000, not on the principle.

Comment: Donations to political candidates or parties are NOT tax-deductible.  But contributions to 501C(3)s ARE tax deductible.  I believe the rule for 501C(3) is that if they devote more than 50% of their time or money to political activity then they lose their tax exemption, because political contributions are not tax exempt.  I recall that several years ago Bishop Estate (now renamed Kamehameha Schools) nearly lost its tax exemption because the IRS investigated and found that their economic profit-making through land investments in Hawaii and the mainland, together with their corrupt political activity in Congress and the state legislature, were the majority of what they were doing.  We can hope that the new Trump administration, and Republican majorities in Senate and House, will result in a much shorter leash for far-left political groups masquerading as non-profit charities and forcing ordinary taxpayers to make up for the taxes which the political activists should otherwise be paying.

Comment: I'm not sure why this is such "great news." This will only improve things once the new dock is built in Mukilteo. Otherwise, it will only result in longer loading times, more delays, and longer lines. 

I wish this paper would stop spreading mis-information regarding the ferries. In an editorial the SWR said that we need overhead loading in Clinton because it's a pedestrian safety issue. That is not at all true. The paper also keeps mentioning a "imbalance in loading times" which is complete bunk and has nothing at all to do with the problems being faced on this run. 

In this age of mis-information, I guess I expect too much for a paper to actually do some research into an issue and not just get on the most popular band-wagon. 

I'm not sure why the Clinton council keeps butting into things. I suppose it's because actual issues in Clinton - such as having owners maintain their commercial properties - are outside of their control, so instead they go for the low-hanging fruit.

Comment: I've been here in the Copper River country for so long that i have Copper River water flowing through my veins. It's nothing unusual to glance out and see a lynx, moose, porcupine, fox, wolf or even a caribou strolling through the yard, or to doze off in a chair on the deck and open my eyes and watch a big black bear lumber past not ten feet away. Or see a splotch of bear nose on the dining window. Or open the kitchen door and see three wide eyed cubs looking up from the trash bags. I go to Anchorage and think, 'My gosh, look at all these people trying to be Alaskans!!!' Then I hurry back home to my little place. And you know what? I just recently discovered that my best friend as a kid was Native. I'd never noticed that before.

Comment: This isn't to defend Cargo (that's an SNL skit), but he and Storey aren't the only problems.  The comeback mode has been scary through most of the season. If they're ahead by 4 runs in the 8th, with 2 on and 2 out, I have every confidence these guys will blow up.  If they're behind by 2 with the bases loaded and nobody out, it's a different story.  

This is why I start scratching the TV when the RootNoobs yammer on about RISP.  Yes, it's better to have a high one than a low one, but context is everything.  I'd rather see a single that drives in 2 runs when they're needed than a grand slam when they aren't.  Also, I'm one of those mouthy fans who loves second guessing bullpen management, but last night was the first time I groaned when Black pulled Chatty.  It wasn't even about the pitching.  I just thought he had as good a chance as anyone of getting a hit.  

With all this said, there's a lot to like and a lot to be hopeful about, imo!

Comment: As a sad sack that endured AB and SK winters for 39 years (Saskatoon residents don't shovel their walks either - lighten up) and now living in the coddled temperate bosom of the Lower Mainland, I have observed that the smug and envious critics of Vancouver and its residents have little understanding of the differences between prairie snow and LM snow.  Edmonton, Regina, and Saskatoon with their relatively flat and straight streets are much easier to navigate than Vancouver's icy, sticky, hilly slop.  And lots of people in SK do not have winter tires either, relying on mislabeled "all season radials" and sliding through intersections into the arms of SGI.  There are numerous complaints in those cities each winter of side streets and cul de sacs never being plowed.  So, give Vancouver a break, people.  The difference rests in that apt prairie saying, "It's a dry cold."

"About 2.2% of U.S. domestic arms sales between 2010 and 2012 were attributable to firearms trafficked across the U.S.-Mexico border. ... The mid-range estimate suggests that the combined seizures of roughly 37,000 firearms by Mexican and U.S. authorities represent roughly 18.2% of the weapons bought for trafficking in recent years... [There are] three gun dealers for every mile of the U.S.-Mexico border."

https://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/firearms-trafficking-u-s-mexico-border

Fast and Furious was an attempt to track some of this illegal trade, and the guns lost represent a drop in the bucket of cross-border smuggling. Right-wingers are angry, not because guns made it across the border, but because the lucrative smuggling trade was being investigated in the first place.
